Variational Language Concepts for Interpreting
Foundation Language Models

Hengyi WangÂ Â Â Â Shiwei TanÂ Â Â Â Zhqing HongÂ Â Â Â Desheng ZhangÂ Â Â Â Hao Wang

Department of Computer Science, Rutgers University Correspondence to: Hengyi Wang <hengyi.wang@rutgers.edu>
Abstract

Foundation Language Models (FLMs) such as BERT and its variants have achieved remarkable success in natural language processing. To date, the interpretability of FLMs has primarily relied on the attention weights in their self-attention layers. However, these attention weights only provide word-level interpretations, failing to capture higher-level structures, and are therefore lacking in readability and intuitiveness. To address this challenge, we first provide a formal definition of conceptual interpretation and then propose a variational Bayesian framework, dubbed VAriational Language Concept (VALC), to go beyond word-level interpretations and provide concept-level interpretations. Our theoretical analysis shows that our VALC finds the optimal language concepts to interpret FLM predictions. Empirical results on several real-world datasets show that our method can successfully provide conceptual interpretation for FLMs111Code will soon be available at https://github.com/Wang-ML-Lab/interpretable-foundation-models.

Variational Language Concepts for Interpreting
Foundation Language Models


Hengyi Wangâ€ â€ thanks: Correspondence to: Hengyi Wang <hengyi.wang@rutgers.edu>Â Â Â Â Shiwei TanÂ Â Â Â Zhqing HongÂ Â Â Â Desheng ZhangÂ Â Â Â Hao Wang Department of Computer Science, Rutgers University


1 Introduction

Foundation language models (FLMs) such as BERTÂ (Devlin etÂ al., 2018) and its variantsÂ (Lan etÂ al., 2019; Liu etÂ al., 2019; He etÂ al., 2021; Portes etÂ al., 2023) have achieved remarkable success in natural language processing. These FLMs are usually large attention-based neural networks that follow a pretrain-finetune paradigm, where models are first pretrained on large datasets and then finetuned for a specific task. As with any machine learning models, interpretability in FLMs has always been a desideratum, especially in decision-critical applications (e.g., healthcare).

To date, FLMsâ€™ interpretability has primarily relied on the attention weights in self-attention layers. However, these attention weights only provide raw word-level importance scores as interpretations. Such low-level interpretations fail to capture higher-level semantic structures, and hence lack readability and intuitiveness. For example, low-level interpretations often fail to capture influence of similar words to predictions, leading to unstable or even unreasonable explanations (see Sec.Â 5.4 for details).

In this paper, we aim to go beyond word-level attention and interpret FLM predictions at the concept level. Such higher-level semantic interpretations are complementary to word-level importance scores and often more readable and intuitive. For example, as shown inÂ Fig.Â 1, VALC interprets the FLM with the following multi-level concepts (details inÂ AppendixÂ F):

  • â€¢

    Dataset-level concepts are highlighted by the top words and the distribution of their embeddings in the PLM (Fig. 1(left)). For example, Concept 20 (Government) corresponds to the red ellipse, encompassing words relevant to government entities and activities, as shown in Fig. 1(left).

  • â€¢

    Document-level concepts are demonstrated by each documentâ€™s topics; for instance, in the 3 bars representing probability distribution over 3 concepts for the document in Fig. 1(middle), VALC identifies Concept 24, i.e., â€˜politicsâ€™, and Concept 20, i.e., â€˜governmentâ€™, as considerably more relevant concepts compared to Concept 27, i.e. â€˜namesâ€™.

  • â€¢

    Word-level concepts are identified by words in documents. For example, in the box displaying the document in Fig. 1(right), VALC highlights the words â€˜chidedâ€™ and â€˜taxâ€™ because they are highly related to Concept 20, i.e., â€˜governmentâ€™. Terms like â€˜Senateâ€™ and â€˜bittyâ€™ are associated with Concept 24, i.e. â€˜politicsâ€™, aligning with the document-level concepts.

We start by developing a comprehensive and formal definition of conceptual interpretation with four desirable properties: (1) multi-level structure, (2) normalization, (3) additivity, and (4) mutual information maximization. With this definition, we then propose a variational Bayesian framework, dubbed VAriational Language Concept (VALC), to provide dataset-level, document-level, and word-level (the first property) conceptual interpretation for FLM predictions. Our theoretical analysis shows that maximizing our VALCâ€™s evidence lower bound is equivalent to inferring the optimal conceptual interpretation with Properties (1-3) while maximizing the mutual information between the inferred concepts and the observed embeddings from FLMs, i.e., Property (4).

Drawing inspiration from hierarchical Bayesian deep learningÂ Wang and Yeung (2016, 2020); Wang etÂ al. (2016), the core of our idea is to treat a FLMâ€™s contextual word embeddings (and their corresponding attention weights) as observed variables and build a probabilistic generative model to automatically infer the higher-level semantic structures (e.g., concepts or topics) from these embeddings and attention weights, thereby interpreting the FLMâ€™s predictions at the concept level. Our VALC is compatible with any attention-based FLMs and can work as an conceptual interpreter, which explains the FLM predictions at multiple levels with theoretical guarantees. Our contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    We identify the problem of multi-level interpretations for FLM predictions, develop a formal definition of conceptual interpretation, and propose VALC as the first general method to infer such conceptual interpretation.

  • â€¢

    Theoretical analysis shows that learning VALC is equivalent to inferring the optimal conceptual interpretation according to our definition.

  • â€¢

    Quantitative and qualitative analysis on real-world datasets show that VALC can infer meaningful language concepts to effectively and intuitively interpret FLM predictions.

2 Related Work

Foundation Language Models. Foundation language models are large attention-based neural networks that follow a pretrain-finetune paradigm. Usually they are first pretrained on large datasets in a self-supervised manner and then finetuned for a specific downstream task. BERTÂ (Devlin etÂ al., 2018) is a pioneering FLM that has shown impressive performance across multiple downstream tasks. Following BERT, there have been variantsÂ He etÂ al. (2021); Clark etÂ al. (2020); Yang etÂ al. (2019); Liu etÂ al. (2019); Lewis etÂ al. (2019) that design different self-supervised learning objectives or training schemes to achieve better performance. While FLMs offer attention weights for interpreting predictions at the word level, these interpretations lack readability and intuitiveness because they fail to capture higher-level semantic structures.

Interpretation Methods for FLMs. Existing conceptual interpretation methods for FLMs typically rely on topic modelsÂ Blei etÂ al. (2003); Blei and Lafferty (2006); Blei (2012); Wang etÂ al. (2012); Chang and Blei (2009); Mcauliffe and Blei (2007); Hoffman etÂ al. (2010) and prototypical part networksÂ Chen etÂ al. (2019). There has been recent work that employs deep neural networks to learn topic models more efficientlyÂ (Card etÂ al., 2017; Xing etÂ al., 2017; Peinelt etÂ al., 2020), using techniques such as amortized variational inference. There is also work that improves upon traditional topic models by either leveraging word similarity as a regularizer for topic-word distributionsÂ (Das etÂ al., 2015; Batmanghelich etÂ al., 2016) or including word embeddings into the generative processÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2012; Dieng etÂ al., 2020; Bunk and Krestel, 2018; Duan etÂ al., 2021). There is also work that builds topic models upon embeddings from FLMsÂ (Grootendorst, 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2022; Wang etÂ al., 2022; Zhao etÂ al., 2020; Meng etÂ al., 2022). However, these methods often rely on a pipeline involving dimensionality reduction and basic clustering, which is not end-to-end, leading to potential information loss between FLM embeddings and clustering outcomes. This can result in unfaithful interpretations for the underlying FLM. Additionally, they typically generate interpretations at a single level (e.g., document level), lacking a multi-level conceptual structure.

Beyond topic models, attribution-based approaches such as LIMEÂ Ribeiro etÂ al. (2016) and SHAPÂ Lundberg and Lee (2017) assign importance to input features to explain predictions. Concept bottleneck models (CBMs)Â Koh etÂ al. (2020); Yuksekgonul etÂ al. (2023); Yang etÂ al. (2023); Kim etÂ al. (2018); Schulz etÂ al. (2020); Paranjape etÂ al. (2020); Schrouff etÂ al. (2021) offer interpretations by learning conceptual activation and then performing classifications on these concepts, while inherent modelsÂ Xie etÂ al. (2023); Ren etÂ al. (2023); Shi etÂ al. (2021) focus on model redesign/re-training for interpretability. However, these approaches often require extra supervision or re-training, making them unsuitable for our setting. In contrast, our method is inherently multi-level and end-to-end, models concepts across dataset, document, and word levels, and produces faithful post-hoc interpretations for any models based on FLMs with theoretical guarantees.

3 Methods

In this section, we formalize the definition of conceptual interpretation, and describe our proposed VALC for conceptual interpretation of FLMs.

3.1 Problem Setting and Notation

and the last-layer CLS token, where hâ„hitalic_h denotes the hâ„hitalic_hâ€™th attention head. We denote the average attention weight over H heads as amâ¢j=1Hâ¢âˆ‘h=1Hamâ¢j(h)subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—1ğ»superscriptsubscriptâ„1ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—â„a_{mj}=\tfrac{1}{H}\sum_{h=1}^{H}a_{mj}^{(h)}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_H end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and correspondingly ğšmâ‰œ[amâ¢j]j=1Jmâ‰œsubscriptğšğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘š{\bf a}_{m}\triangleq[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see the FLM at the bottom of Fig.Â 2).

In FLMs, these last-layer CLS embeddings are used as document-level representations for downstream tasks (e.g., document classification). Furthermore, our VALC assumes Kğ¾Kitalic_K concepts (topics) for the corpus. For document mğ‘šmitalic_m, our VALC interpreter tries to infer a concept distribution vector ğœ½mâˆˆâ„Ksubscriptğœ½ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ¾\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (also known as the topic proportion in topic models) for the whole document and a concept distribution vector Ï•mâ¢j=[Ï•mâ¢jâ¢k]k=1Kâˆˆâ„Ksubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptâ„ğ¾\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}=[\phi_{mjk}]_{k=1}^{K}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for word jğ‘—jitalic_j in document mğ‘šmitalic_m. In our continuous embedding space, the kğ‘˜kitalic_kâ€™th concept is represented by a Gaussian distribution, ğ’©â¢(ğk,ğšºk)ğ’©subscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k})caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), of contextual word embeddings; we use shorthand ğ›€k=(ğk,ğšºk)subscriptğ›€ğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})bold_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for brevity. The goal is to interpret FLMsâ€™ predictions at the concept level using the inferred document-level concept vector ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, word-level concept vector Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the learned embedding distributions {ğ’©â¢(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptğ’©subscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K}{ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for each concept (seeÂ Sec.Â 5.4 for detailed descriptions and visualizations).

3.2 Formal Definition of Language Concepts

Below we formally define â€˜conceptual interpretationâ€™ for FLM predictions (see notations inÂ Sec.Â 3.1):

Definition 3.1 (Conceptual Interpretation).

Assume Kğ¾Kitalic_K concepts and a dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D containing Mğ‘€Mitalic_M documents, each with Jmsubscriptğ½ğ‘šJ_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT words (1â‰¤mâ‰¤M1ğ‘šğ‘€1\leq m\leq M1 â‰¤ italic_m â‰¤ italic_M). Conceptual interpretation for a document mğ‘šmitalic_m consists of Kğ¾Kitalic_K dataset-level variables {ğ›€k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ›€ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a document-level variable ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Jmsubscriptğ½ğ‘šJ_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT word-level variables {Ï•mâ¢j}j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘š\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{ bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the following properties:

  1. (1)

    Multi-Level Structure. Conceptual interpretation has a three-level structure:

    1. (a)

      Each dataset-level variable ğ›€k=(ğk,ğšºk)subscriptğ›€ğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})bold_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) describes the kğ‘˜kitalic_kâ€™th concept; ğkâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğšºkâˆˆâ„dÃ—dsubscriptğšºğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d\times d}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the mean and covariance of the kğ‘˜kitalic_kâ€™th concept in the embedding space (i.e., ğmâ¢jâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bf e}_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), respectively.

    2. (b)

      Each document-level variable ğœ½mâˆˆâ„â‰¥0Ksubscriptğœ½ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ¾absent0\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}_{\geq 0}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT describes document mğ‘šmitalic_mâ€™s relation to the Kğ¾Kitalic_K concepts.

    3. (c)

      Each word-level variable Ï•mâ¢jâˆˆâ„â‰¥0Ksubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ¾absent0\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}_{\geq 0}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT describes word jğ‘—jitalic_jâ€™s relation to the Kğ¾Kitalic_K concepts.

  2. (2)

    Normalization.Â The document- and word-level interpretations, ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are normalized:

    1. (a)

      âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸mâ¢k=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘˜1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for document mğ‘šmitalic_m.

    2. (b)

      âˆ‘k=1KÏ•mâ¢jâ¢k=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for word jğ‘—jitalic_j in document mğ‘šmitalic_m.

  3. (3)

    Additivity.Â We can add/subtract the kğ‘˜kitalic_kâ€™s concept from the contextual embeddings ğmâ¢jsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of word jğ‘—jitalic_j in document mğ‘šmitalic_m, i.e., ğmâ¢jâ†ğmâ¢jÂ±xkâ¢ğkâ†subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—plus-or-minussubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜{\bf e}_{mj}\leftarrow{\bf e}_{mj}\pm x_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â± italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the editing weight of concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k).

  4. (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization. The conceptual interpretation achieves maximum mutual information between the observed embeddings ğmsubscriptğğ‘š{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in FLMs and the document-level/word-level interpretation, ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

InÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1, Property (1) provides comprehensive three-level conceptual interpretation for FLM predictions, Property (2) ensures proper normalization in concept assignment at the document and word levels, Property (3) enables better concept editing (more details inÂ Sec.Â 5.3) to modify FLM predictions, and Property (4) ensures minimal information loss when interpreting FLM predictions.

3.3 VAriational Language Concepts (VALC)

Method Overview. Drawing inspiration from hierarchical Bayesian deep learningÂ Wang and Yeung (2016, 2020); Wang etÂ al. (2016); Mao etÂ al. (2022); Yan and Wang (2023); Xu etÂ al. (2023); Wang etÂ al. (2024), we propose our model, VAriational Language Concepts (VALC), to infer the optimal conceptual interpretation described inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1. Different from static word embeddingsÂ (Mikolov etÂ al., 2013) and topic models, FLMs produce contextual word embeddings with continuous-value entries [ğmâ¢j]j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘š[{\bf e}_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}[ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and more importantly, associate each word embedding with a continuous-value attention weight [amâ¢j]j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘š[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}[ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; therefore this brings unique challenges.

To effectively discover latent concept structures learned by FLMs at the dataset level and interpret FLM predictions at the data-instance level, our VALC treats both the contextual word embeddings and their associated attention weights as observations to learn a probabilistic generative model of these observations, as shown in Fig.Â 2. The key idea is to use the attention weights from FLMs to compute a virtual continuous count for each word, and model the contextual word embedding distributions with Gaussian mixtures. The generative process of VALC is as follows (we mark key connection to FLMs in blue and show the corresponding graphical model inÂ Fig.Â 3):

For each document m,1â‰¤mâ‰¤Mğ‘š1ğ‘šğ‘€m,1\leq m\leq Mitalic_m , 1 â‰¤ italic_m â‰¤ italic_M,

  1. 1.

    Draw the document-level concept distribution vector ğœ½mâˆ¼Dirichletâ¢(ğœ¶)similar-tosubscriptğœ½ğ‘šDirichletğœ¶\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\sim\text{Dirichlet}(\mbox{\boldmath$% \alpha$\unboldmath})bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ Dirichlet ( bold_italic_Î± ).

  2. 2.

    For each word jğ‘—jitalic_j (1â‰¤jâ‰¤Jm)1ğ‘—subscriptğ½ğ‘š(1\leq j\leq J_{m})( 1 â‰¤ italic_j â‰¤ italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

    1. (a)

      Draw the word-level concept index zmâ¢jâˆ¼Categoricalâ¢(ğœ½m)similar-tosubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—Categoricalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šz_{mj}\sim\text{Categorical}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ Categorical ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

    2. (b)

      With a continuous word count wmâ¢jâˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—â„w_{mj}\in\mathbb{R}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R from the FLMâ€™s attention weights, draw the contextual word embedding of the FLM from the corresponding Gaussian component ğmâ¢jâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(ğzmâ¢j,ğšºzmâ¢j)similar-tosubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—ğ’©subscriptğsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—{\bf e}_{mj}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Given the generative process above, discovery of latent concept structures in FLMs at the dataset level boils down to learning the parameters {ğk,ğšºk}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% \}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the Kğ¾Kitalic_K concepts. Intuitively the global parameters {ğk,ğšºk}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% \}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are shared across different documents, and they define a mixture of Kğ¾Kitalic_K Gaussian distributions. Each Gaussian distribution describes a â€˜clusterâ€™ of words and their contextual word embeddings.

Similarly, interpretations of FLM predictions at the data-instance level is equivalent to inferring the latent variables, i.e., document-level concept distribution vectors ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and word-level concept indices zmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Below we highlight several important aspects of our VALC designs.

Attention Weights as Continuous Word Counts. Different from typical topic modelsÂ (Blei etÂ al., 2003; Blei, 2012) and word embeddingsÂ (Mikolov etÂ al., 2013) that can only handle discrete word counts, our VALC can handle continuous (virtual) word counts; this better aligns with continuous attention weights in FLMs. Specifically, we denote as wmâ¢jâˆˆâ„â‰¥0subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptâ„absent0w_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{\geq 0}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the (non-negative real-valued) continuous word count for the jğ‘—jitalic_jâ€™th word in document mğ‘šmitalic_m. We explore three schemes of computing wmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

  • â€¢

    Identical Weights: Use identical weights for different words, i.e., wmâ¢j=1,âˆ€m,jsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—1for-allğ‘šğ‘—w_{mj}=1,\forall m,jitalic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , âˆ€ italic_m , italic_j. This is equivalent to typical discrete word counts.

  • â€¢

    Attention-Based Weights with Fixed Length: Use wmâ¢j=Jâ€²â¢amâ¢jsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—superscriptğ½â€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—w_{mj}=J^{\prime}a_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Jâ€²superscriptğ½â€²J^{\prime}italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a fixed sequence length shared across all documents.

  • â€¢

    Attention-Based Weights with Variable Length: Use wmâ¢j=Jmâ¢amâ¢j/âˆ‘i=1Jmamâ¢isubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘–w_{mj}=\nicefrac{{J_{m}a_{mj}}}{{\sum_{i=1}^{J_{m}}a_{mi}}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = / start_ARG italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, where Jmsubscriptğ½ğ‘šJ_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is true sequence length without padding. Note that in practice, âˆ‘i=1Jmamâ¢iâ‰ 1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘–1\sum_{i=1}^{J_{m}}a_{mi}\neq 1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  1 due to padding tokens in FLMs.

Contextual Continuous Word Representations. Note that different from topic modelsÂ (Blei etÂ al., 2003) and typical word embeddingsÂ (Mikolov etÂ al., 2013; Dieng etÂ al., 2020) where word representations are static, word representations in FLMs are contextual; specifically, the same word can have different embeddings in different documents (contexts). For example, the word â€˜softâ€™ can appear as the j1subscriptğ‘—1j_{1}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™th word in document m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and as the j2subscriptğ‘—2j_{2}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™th word in document m2subscriptğ‘š2m_{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and therefore have two different embeddings (i.e., ğm1â¢j1â‰ ğm2â¢j2subscriptğsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘—1subscriptğsubscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘—2{\bf e}_{m_{1}j_{1}}\neq{\bf e}_{m_{2}j_{2}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Correspondingly, in our VALC, we do not constrain the same word to have a static embedding; instead we assume that a word embedding is drawn from a Gaussian distribution corresponding to its latent topic. Note that word representations in our VALC is continuous, which is different from typical topic modelsÂ (Blei etÂ al., 2003) based on (discrete) bag-of-words representations.

3.4 Objective Function

Below we discuss the inference and learning procedure for VALC. We start by introducing the inference of document-level and word-level concepts (i.e., zmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) given the global concept parameters (i.e., {(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), and then introduce the learning of these global concept parameters.

3.4.1 Inference

Inferring Document-Level and Word-Level Concepts. We formulate the problem of interpreting FLM predictions at the concept level as inferring document-level and word-level concepts. Specifically, given global concept parameters {(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the contextual word embeddings ğmâ‰œ[ğmâ¢j]j=1Jmâ‰œsubscriptğğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘š{\bf e}_{m}\triangleq[{\bf e}_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the associated attention weights ğšmâ‰œ[amâ¢j]j=1Jmâ‰œsubscriptğšğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘š{\bf a}_{m}\triangleq[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a FLM produces for each document mğ‘šmitalic_m, our VALC infers the posterior distribution of the document-level concept vector ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., pâ¢(ğœ½m|ğm,ğšm,{(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1K)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šsubscriptğğ‘šsubscriptğšğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|{\bf e}_{m},{\bf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and the posterior distribution of the word-level concept index zmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., pâ¢(zmâ¢j|ğm,ğšm,{(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1K)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘šsubscriptğšğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾p(z_{mj}|{\bf e}_{m},{\bf a}_{m},\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox% {\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Variational Distributions. These posterior distributions are intractable; we therefore resort to variational inferenceÂ (Jordan etÂ al., 1998; Blei etÂ al., 2003) and use variational distributions qâ¢(ğœ½m|ğœ¸m)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šsubscriptğœ¸ğ‘šq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and qâ¢(zmâ¢j|Ï•mâ¢j)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—q(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to approximate them. Here ğœ¸mâˆˆâ„Ksubscriptğœ¸ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ¾\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Ï•mâ¢jâ‰œ[Ï•mâ¢jâ¢k]k=1Kâˆˆâ„Kâ‰œsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptâ„ğ¾\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\triangleq[\phi_{mjk}]_{k=1}^{K}\in{% \mathbb{R}}^{K}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ [ italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are variational parameters to be estimated during inference. This leads to the following joint variational distribution:

Evidence Lower Bound. For each document mğ‘šmitalic_m, finding the optimal variational distributions is then equivalent to maximizing the following evidence lower bound (ELBO):

âˆ’ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡qâ¢(ğœ½m)]âˆ’âˆ‘j=1Jmğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡qâ¢(zmâ¢j)],subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğœ½ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle-{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})% ]-\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log q(z_{mj})],- blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , (2)

where the expectation is taken over the joint variational distribution inÂ Eq.Â 1.

Likelihood with Continuous Word Counts. One key difference between VALC and typical topic modelsÂ (Blei etÂ al., 2003; Blei, 2012) is the virtual continuous (real-valued) word counts (discussed inÂ Sec.Â 3.3). Specifically, we define the likelihood in the third term of Eq.Â 2 as:

pâ¢(ğmâ¢j|zmâ¢j,ğzmâ¢j,ğšºzmâ¢j)=[ğ’©â¢(ğmâ¢j;ğmâ¢j,ğšºmâ¢j)]wmâ¢j.ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—superscriptdelimited-[]ğ’©subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})=[{\mathcal{N}}({\bf e}_{mj};% \mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{mj}% )]^{w_{mj}}.italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3)

Note that Eq.Â 3 is the likelihood of wmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (virtual) words, where wmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a real value derived from the FLMâ€™s attention weights (details in Sec.Â 3.3). Therefore, in the third item of Eq.Â 2, we have:

ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ğmâ¢j|zmâ¢j,ğzmâ¢j,ğšºzmâ¢j)]subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]

=\displaystyle=~{}= âˆ‘kÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kwmâ¢j{âˆ’12(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)Tğšºkâˆ’1(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{{k}}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-% \mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{% k}^{-1}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
âˆ’log[(2Ï€)d/2|ğšºk|1/2]}.\displaystyle-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}% ]\}.- roman_log [ ( 2 italic_Ï€ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (4)

Update Rules. Taking the derivative of the ELBO in Eq.Â 2 w.r.t. Ï•mâ¢jâ¢kâˆproportional-tosubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜absent\displaystyle\phi_{mjk}\propto~{}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ wmâ¢j|ğšºk|1/2exp[Î¨(Î³mâ¢k)âˆ’Î¨(âˆ‘kâ€²Î³mâ¢kâ€²)\displaystyle\tfrac{w_{mj}}{|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}}% \exp[\Psi(\gamma_{mk})-\Psi(\sum\nolimits_{k^{\prime}}\gamma_{mk^{\prime}})divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG | bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_exp [ roman_Î¨ ( italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Î¨ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
âˆ’12(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)Tğšºkâˆ’1(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)],\displaystyle-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^% {T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})],- divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , (5)

with the normalization constraint âˆ‘k=1KÏ•mâ¢jâ¢k=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.

Î³mâ¢k=Î±k+âˆ‘j=1JmÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢j,subscriptğ›¾ğ‘šğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle\gamma_{mk}=\alpha_{k}+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj},italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (6)

where ğœ¶â‰œ[Î±k]k=1Kâ‰œğœ¶superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}\triangleq[\alpha_{k}]_{k=1}^{K}bold_italic_Î± â‰œ [ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the hyperparameter for the Dirichlet prior distribution of ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In summary, the inference algorithm will alternate between updating Ï•mâ¢jâ¢ksubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜\phi_{mjk}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all (m,j,k)ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜(m,j,k)( italic_m , italic_j , italic_k ) tuples and updating ğœ¸mâ¢ksubscriptğœ¸ğ‘šğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{mk}bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all (m,k)ğ‘šğ‘˜(m,k)( italic_m , italic_k ) tuples.

3.4.2 Learning

Learning Dataset-Level Concept Parameters. The inference algorithm inÂ Sec.Â 3.4.1 assumes availability of the dataset-level (global) concept parameters {(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To learn these parameters, one needs to iterate between (1) inferring document-level variational parameters ğœ¸msubscriptğœ¸ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well as word-level variational parameters Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Sec.Â 3.4.1 and (2) learning dataset-level concept parameters {(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Update Rules. Similar toÂ Sec.Â 3.4.1, we expand the ELBO inÂ Eq.Â 2 (seeÂ AppendixÂ A for details) and set its derivative w.r.t. ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to ğŸ0{\bf 0}bold_0, yielding the update rule for learning ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

ğk=subscriptğğ‘˜absent\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}=~{}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘m,jÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢jâ¢ğmâ¢jâˆ‘m,jÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢j,subscriptğ‘šğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘šğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}{\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}{\bf e}_{mj}}}{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{% mjk}w_{mj}},divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,
ğšºk=subscriptğšºğ‘˜absent\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}=~{}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘m,jÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢jâ¢(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)â¢(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)Tâˆ‘m,jÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢j.subscriptğ‘šğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘šğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}}{% \sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}}.divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (7)

Effect of Attention Weights. From Eq.Â 7, we can observe that the attention weight of the jğ‘—jitalic_jâ€™th word in document mğ‘šmitalic_m, i.e., amâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—a_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, affects the virtual continuous word count wmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (seeÂ Sec.Â 3.3), thereby affecting the update of the dataset-level concept center ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and covariance ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Specifically, if we use attention-based weights with fixed length or variable length inÂ Sec.Â 3.3, the continuous word count wmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be proportional to the attention weight amâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—a_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, when updating the concept center ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a weighted average of different word embeddings ğmâ¢jsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, VALC naturally places more focus on words with higher attention weights amâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—a_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from FLMs, thereby making the interpretations sharper (seeÂ Sec.Â 5.4 for detailed results andÂ AppendixÂ I for theoretical analysis).

4 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we provide theoretical guarantees of VALC on the four properties inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1.

Multi-Level Structure. As shown inÂ Alg.Â 1, VALC (1) learns the dataset-level interpretation {ğ›€k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ›€ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT describing the Kğ¾Kitalic_K concepts, (2) infers the distribution of document-level interpretation ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document mğ‘šmitalic_m, i.e., qâ¢(ğœ½m|ğœ¸m)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šsubscriptğœ¸ğ‘šq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (parameterized by ğœ¸msubscriptğœ¸ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and (3) infers the posterior distribution of word-level concept index, i.e., qâ¢(zmâ¢j|Ï•mâ¢j)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—q(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), parameterized by Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Such three-level interpretations correspond to Property (1) inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1.

Normalization. The learned variational distribution qâ¢(ğœ½m|ğœ¸m)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šsubscriptğœ¸ğ‘šq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (described in Eq.Â 1) is a Dirichlet distribution; therefore we have âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸mâ¢k=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘˜1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. The update of Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Eq.Â 3.4.1) is naturally constrained by âˆ‘k=1KÏ•mâ¢jâ¢k=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 since Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT parameterizes a Categorical distribution (over zmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Additivity. VALC is able to perform Concept Editing, i.e, add/subtract the learned concept activation Î¼ksubscriptğœ‡ğ‘˜\mu_{k}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from FLMs via the following Quadratic Programming (QP) problem (ğ±=[xk]k=1Kğ±superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾{\bf x}=[x_{k}]_{k=1}^{K}bold_x = [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT):

minğ±âˆˆâ„Ksubscriptğ±superscriptâ„ğ¾\displaystyle\min\nolimits_{{\bf x}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}}\quadroman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€–âˆ‘k=1Kxkâ¢ğkâˆ’ğmâ€–2,superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘š2\displaystyle\|\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}x_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k% }-{\bf e}_{m}\|^{2},âˆ¥ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,
subject to ğ±â‰¥ğŸâ¢Â andÂ â¢âˆ‘k=1Kxk=1.ğ±0Â andÂ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1\displaystyle{\bf x}\geq{\bf 0}\mbox{~{}~{}and~{}~{}}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}x_% {k}=1.bold_x â‰¥ bold_0 and âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 . (8)

Given learned concepts {(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, VALC obtains this QPâ€™s optimal solution ğ±âˆ—âˆˆâ„Ksuperscriptğ±superscriptâ„ğ¾{\bf x}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and add/subtract any concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k from arbitrary FLM embedding ğmsubscriptğğ‘š{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by: ğmâ†ğmÂ±xkâˆ—â¢ğk.â†subscriptğğ‘šplus-or-minussubscriptğğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜{\bf e}_{m}\leftarrow{\bf e}_{m}\pm x^{*}_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_% {k}.bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â± italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Alg.Â 2 summarizes this concept editing process; one can also replace ğmâ¢jsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the CLS embedding ğœmsubscriptğœğ‘š{\bf c}_{m}bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document-level editing (details inÂ AppendixÂ 3).

Mutual Information Maximization. TheoremÂ 4.1 below shows that our inferred document-level and word-level interpretation, ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and {Ï•mâ¢j}j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘š\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{ bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, satisfy Property (4), Mutual Information Maximization, inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1.

Theorem 4.1 (Mutual Information Maximization).

InÂ Eq.Â 2, the ELBO â„’â¢(ğ›„m,{Ï•mâ¢j}j=1Jm;ğ›‚,{(ğ›k,ğšºk)}k=1K)â„’subscriptğ›„ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ›‚superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ›ğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$% \unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{(\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=% 1}^{K})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î± , { ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is upper bounded by the mutual information between contextual embeddings ğmsubscriptğğ‘š{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and multi-level interpretation ğ›‰m,{Ï•mâ¢j}j=1Jmsubscriptğ›‰ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{% mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1. Formally, with approximate posteriors qâ¢(ğ›‰m|ğ›„m)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ›‰ğ‘šsubscriptğ›„ğ‘šq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and qâ¢(zmâ¢j|Ï•mâ¢j)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptbold-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—q(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we have

â„’â„’\displaystyle\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L (ğœ¸m,{Ï•mâ¢j}j=1Jm;ğœ¶,{(ğk,ğšºk)}k=1K)subscriptğœ¸ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šğœ¶superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\displaystyle(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$% \unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{(\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=% 1}^{K})( bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î± , { ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq~{}â‰¤ Iâ¢(ğm;ğœ½m,{zmâ¢j}j=1Jm)âˆ’Hâ¢(ğm),ğ¼subscriptğğ‘šsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ»subscriptğğ‘š\displaystyle{I}({\bf e}_{m};\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},\{z_{mj}% \}_{j=1}^{J_{m}})-H({\bf e}_{m}),italic_I ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (9)

where the entropy term Hâ¢(ğm)ğ»subscriptğğ‘šH({\bf e}_{m})italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a constant.

From TheoremÂ 4.1 we can see that maximizing the ELBO inÂ Eq.Â 2 is equivalent to maximizing the mutual information between our document-level/word-level concepts and the observed contextual embeddings in FLMs (proof inÂ AppendixÂ H).

In summary, VALC enjoys all four properties inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1 and therefore generates the optimal conceptual interpretation for FLMs. In contrast, state-of-the-art methods only satisfy a small part of them (TableÂ 1 andÂ Sec.Â 5.2). InÂ AppendixÂ I, we provide theoretical guarantees that (1) under mild assumptions our VALC can learn better conceptual interpretations for FLMs for in noisy data and (2) attention-based schemes is superior to the identical scheme (described in Sec.Â 3.3).

5 Experiments

5.1 Experiment Setup

Datasets. We use three datasets in our experiments, namely 20 Newsgroups, M10Â (Lim and Buntine, 2015), and BBC NewsÂ (Greene and Cunningham, 2006). For preprocessing details, seeÂ AppendixÂ C.

Baselines. We compare our method with the following state-of-the-art baselines:

  • â€¢

    SHAP and LIMEÂ (Lundberg and Lee, 2017; Ribeiro etÂ al., 2016) are interpretation methods that attribute importance scores to input features. In this paper, we use embeddings of â€˜CLSâ€™ token as input to SHAP/LIME.

  • â€¢

    BERTopicÂ (Grootendorst, 2020) is a clustering-based model that uses HDBSCANÂ (McInnes and Healy, 2017) to cluster sentence embeddings from BERT, performs Uniform Manifold Approximation Projection (UMAP)Â (McInnes etÂ al., 2018), and then uses class-based TF-IDF (c-TF-IDF) to obtain words for each cluster.

  • â€¢

    CETopicÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022) is a clustering-based model that first uses UMAP to perform dimensionality reduction on BERT sentence embeddings, performs K-Means clusteringÂ (Lloyd, 1982), and then uses weighted word selection for each cluster.

Evaluation Metric. Inspired byÂ Koh etÂ al. (2020), we perform concept editing experiments to evaluate conceptual interpretation for FLMs; higher accuracy gain after editing indicates better interpretation performance. We leverage BERT-base-uncasedÂ (Devlin etÂ al., 2018) as the contextual embedding model, and use accuracy on the test set as our metric. For a fair comparison, we adhered to the baseline methodologies (e.g., BERTopic and CETopic) by setting the number of concepts (topics) Kğ¾Kitalic_K to 100 across all datasets. This number was chosen as it strikes an effective balance between capturing adequate detail and avoiding model overfitting. SeeÂ AppendixÂ D for more details.

We can perform concept editing on either input tokens or contextual embeddings of FLMs. Specifically, we can perform hard concept editing for concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k by directly removing tokens that belong concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k (applicable for hard clustering methods such as our baselines); we could also perform soft concept editing for concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k by removing concept subspace vectors from contextual embeddings ğmsubscriptğğ‘š{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (applicable for VALC usingÂ Alg.Â 2).

FollowingÂ Lyu etÂ al. (2024), we conducted additional experiments to evaluate the faithfulness metric. The faithfulness metric is implemented as the accuracy score of predictions using logistic regression, with the inferred conceptual explanations as inputs.

5.2 Comparison on Four Properties inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1

InÂ Sec.Â 4 we show that VALC satisfies the four properties of conceptual interpretation inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1. In contrast, baseline models do not necessarily learn concepts that meet these requirements. TableÂ 1 summarizes the comparison between VALC and the baselines. We can see that VALC is superior to baselines in terms of the following four aspects:

  1. (1)

    Multi-Level Structure. Baselines either apply clustering algorithms directly on the document-level embeddings from FLMs or assign importance scores to input features, and thus can only provide single-level interpretation, necessitating complex post-processing to generate dataset-level concepts. In contrast, VALC adopts an integrated approach, learning concepts at the dataset, document, and word level in a joint, end-to-end manner.

  2. (2)

    Normalization. BERTopic and CETopic assign each word to exactly one concept and therefore satisfies hard-normalization. SHAP/LIME produce importance scores that are not normalized. In contrast, VALC learns fractional concept interpretations ğœ¸msubscriptğœ¸ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and therefore satisfies soft-normalization, which is more flexible and intuitive.

  3. (3)

    Additivity. Baselines perform addition or subtraction of concepts only at a single level (word/document), while our additivity and concept editing (Alg.Â 2) work for both levels.

  4. (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization. Baselines either use a multi-step pipeline or produce importance scores; they are therefore prone to lose information between FLM embeddings and final clustering/scoring results. In contrast, VALC is theoretically guaranteed to maximally preserve information (TheoremÂ 4.1).

5.3 Results

Accuracy Gain. We perform greedy concept editingÂ (Koh etÂ al., 2020) for BERTopic, CETopic, and our VALC to evaluate the quality of their learned concepts. Higher accuracy gain after pruning indicates better performance.

TableÂ 2 show the results for different methods in three real-world datasets, where â€˜Finetune (Oracle)â€™ refers to finetuning both the backbone and the classifier of BERT. VALCâ€™s concept editing can improve the accuracy upon the unedited model by more than 11%percent1111\%11 % in 20 Newsgroups and M10, almost on par with â€˜Finetune (Oracle)â€™. Compared with the baselines, VALC achieves the most accuracy gain in 20 Newsgroups and M10 and the second most accuracy gain in BBC News, demonstrating the effectiveness of VALCâ€™s four properties inÂ DefinitionÂ 3.1. Note that SHAP and LIME both interpret the CLS tokenâ€™s embedding and therefore has identical accuracy gain (details inÂ AppendixÂ D).

Ablation Study. Thanks to its full additivity (DefinitionÂ 3.1), VALC is capable of different concept editing schemes, including â€˜Randomâ€™, â€˜Unweightedâ€™, and â€˜Weightedâ€™. Specifically, weighted pruning uses the concept editing algorithm inÂ Alg.Â 2 with the optimal hyperparameter Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰; unweighted pruning runsÂ Alg.Â 2 with Ï‰=1ğœ”1\omega=1italic_Ï‰ = 1; random pruning first randomly picks a concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k (kâˆˆ{1,â€¦,K}ğ‘˜1â€¦ğ¾k\in\{1,...,K\}italic_k âˆˆ { 1 , â€¦ , italic_K }), sets Ï‰â‹…xk=1/Kâ‹…ğœ”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1ğ¾\omega\cdot x_{k}=1/Kitalic_Ï‰ â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 / italic_K, and then runsÂ Alg.Â 2.

TableÂ 3 shows accuracy for VALCâ€™s different schemes. As expected, random pruning barely improves upon the unedited model. Unweighted pruning improves upon the unedited model by 1.5âˆ¼3.5%similar-to1.5percent3.51.5\sim 3.5\%1.5 âˆ¼ 3.5 %. Weighted pruning improves the accuracy by around 11%percent1111\%11 % upon the unedited model on 20 Newsgroups and M10.

Faithfulness. TableÂ 4 shows the faithfulness of VALC and baselines on the 20 Newsgroups, M10, and BBC News datasets. These results show that our VALC significantly outperforms the baseline models, achieving the highest faithfulness accuracy scores in the 20 Newsgroups (89.8%percent89.889.8\%89.8 %), M10 (99.5%percent99.599.5\%99.5 %), and BBC News (100.0%percent100.0100.0\%100.0 %) datasets.

Note that the dataset size of 20 Newsgroups, M10, and BBC News is 16,3091630916{,}30916 , 309, 8,35583558{,}3558 , 355, and 2,22522252{,}2252 , 225, respectively. BBC News contains significantly less data, making it easier to achieve a high faithfulness score. This explains why both CETopic and our VALC obtain a faithfulness score of 100.0%percent100.0100.0\%100.0 %.

Baseline methods such as BERTopic and CETopic represent language concepts as discrete bags of words, which lack flexibility and accuracy. In contrast, VALC infers continuous concepts for datasets, documents, and words with theoretical guarantees. Consequently, it provides optimal and faithful conceptual explanations of high quality.

SeeÂ AppendixÂ G for more quantitative results.

5.4 Conceptual Interpretation (More for Different Tasks inÂ AppendixÂ F)

Dataset-Level Interpretations. As a case study, we train VALC on M10, sample 6666 concepts (topics) from the dataset, and plot the word embeddings of the top words (closest to the center ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in these concepts using PCA in Fig.Â 4(left and middle). We can observe Concept 5 is mostly about data analysis, including words such as â€˜samplingâ€™ and â€˜similarityâ€™. Concept 84 is mostly about reasoning, with words â€˜exploreâ€™, â€™acceptâ€™, â€˜explainâ€™, etc. Concept 62 is mostly about nature, with words â€˜environmentâ€™, â€˜formationâ€™, â€˜growthâ€™, etc. Concept 98 is mostly about farming, with words â€˜termâ€™, â€˜summerâ€™, â€˜heatingâ€™, etc. Concept 24 is mostly about economics, with words â€˜forthcomingâ€™, â€˜prospectâ€™, â€˜growâ€™, etc. ConceptÂ 74 is mostly about social contact, containing words such as â€˜peerâ€™, â€˜connectâ€™, and â€˜collaborativeâ€™. Interestingly, Concept 24 (economics) and ConceptÂ 74 (social contact) are both related to social science and are therefore closer to each other in Fig.Â 4(middle), while Concept 98 (farming) is farther away, showing VALCâ€™s cability of capturing concept similarity.

Document-Level Interpretations. Fig.Â 4(right) shows that VALC can provide conceptual interpretations on why correct or incorrect FLM predictions happen for specific documents. For example, document (e) belongs to class 2 (biology), but BERT misclassifies it as class 9 (social science); our VALC interprets that this is because document (e) involves Concept 24 (economics), which is related to social science. On the other hand, document (b) is related to machine learning and BERT correctly classifies it as class 3 (computer science); VALC interprets that this is because document (b) involves Concept 5 (data analysis).

Word-Level Interpretations. Fig.Â 4(right) also shows that VALC can interpret which words and what concepts of these words lead to specific FLM predictions. For example, documentÂ (f) belongs to class 7 (petroleum chemistry), but BERT misclassifies it as class 0 (agriculture); VALC attributes this to the word â€˜airâ€™, which belongs to Concept 98 (farming). For documentÂ (b), VALC interprets that BERT correctly classifies it as class 3 (computer science) because the document contains the word â€˜kernelâ€™ that belongs to Concept 5 (data analysis).

6 Conclusion

We address the challenge of multi-level interpretations for FLM predictions by defining conceptual interpretation and introducing VALC, the first method to infer such interpretations effectively. Empirical results are promising, and theoretical analysis confirms that VALC reliably produces optimal conceptual interpretations by our definition.

7 Limitations

Our proposed method assumes access to the hidden layers of Transformer-based models, and therefore can be naturally extended to Transformer-based models including RoBERTaÂ Liu etÂ al. (2019), DeBERTaÂ He etÂ al. (2021), ALBERTÂ Lan etÂ al. (2019), ElectraÂ Clark etÂ al. (2020), and decoder-only models, such as GPTsÂ Radford etÂ al. (2019); Brown (2020). Although our VALC is initially designed for Transformer-based models, it is also generalizable to other architectures, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)Â LeCun etÂ al. (2015) and Long Short-Term Memory networks (LSTMs)Â Hochreiter and Schmidhuber (1997), by simply setting identical attention weights. Future work may include extending VALC beyond Transformer variants and natural language applications. However, many other foundation language models provided by proprietary sources may not expose their internal states, limiting the applicability of our method in such cases.

8 Ethical Considerations

VALC, as the first to comprehensively interpret FLMs at the concept level, holds significant promise for advancing societal and technological progress. By elucidating the inner workings of these complex FLMs, we enable greater transparency and trust in AI systems, which is crucial for their widespread adoption. This transparency ensures that AI-driven decisions in critical areas such as healthcare, law, and finance are more explainable and accountable, thus safeguarding against biases and errors. Additionally, our VALC fosters enhanced collaboration between AI and human experts, as interpretable models can provide insights that are more easily understood and acted upon by domain specialists. This symbiotic relationship has the potential to accelerate innovation, improve decision-making processes, and ultimately lead to more ethical and equitable AI applications, thereby benefiting society at large.

9 Acknowledgements

We extend our sincere gratitude to Akshay Nambi and Tanuja Ganu from Microsoft Research for their invaluable insights and guidance, which significantly enhanced the quality of this work. We also express our deep appreciation to Microsoft Research AI & Society Fellowship, NSF Grant IIS-2127918, NSF CAREER Award IIS-2340125, NIH Grant 1R01CA297832, and the Amazon Faculty Research Award for their generous support. This research is also supported by NSF National Artificial Intelligence Research Resource (NAIRR) Pilot and the Frontera supercomputer supported by the National Science Foundation (award NSF-OAC 1818253) at the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) at The University of Texas at Austin. Additionally, we thank the anonymous reviewers and the area chair/senior area chair for their thoughtful feedback and for recognizing the significance and contributions of our research. Finally, we would like to thank the Center for AI Safety (CAIS) for providing the essential computing resources that enabled this work.

Appendix A Details on Learning VALC

Update Rules. Similar to Sec. 3.4.1 of the main paper, we expand the ELBO inÂ Eq.Â 2 of the main paper, take its derivative w.r.t. ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and set it to ğŸ0{\bf 0}bold_0:
