we have

ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =âˆ‘m,jÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢jâ¢(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)â¢(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)Tâˆ‘m,jÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢j.absentsubscriptğ‘šğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘šğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle=\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}}{% \sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}}.= divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (13)

Smoothing with Prior Distributions on {(Î¼k,ğšºk)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To alleviate overfitting and prevent singularity in numerical computation, we impose priors distributions on ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to smooth the learning process (Fig.Â 5). Specifically, we use a Normal-Inverse-Wishart prior on ğisubscriptğğ‘–\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšºisubscriptğšºğ‘–\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼â„â¢ğ’²â¢(ğš²0,Î½0),similar-toabsentâ„ğ’²subscriptğš²0subscriptğœˆ0\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{IW}(\mbox{\boldmath$\Lambda$\unboldmath}_{0},\nu_{0}),âˆ¼ caligraphic_I caligraphic_W ( bold_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,
ğk|ğšºkconditionalsubscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(ğ0,ğšºk/Îº0),similar-toabsentğ’©subscriptğ0subscriptğšºğ‘˜subscriptğœ…0\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0},\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}/\kappa_{0}),âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where ğš²0subscriptğš²0\mbox{\boldmath$\Lambda$\unboldmath}_{0}bold_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Î½0subscriptğœˆ0\nu_{0}italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ0subscriptğ0\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Îº0subscriptğœ…0\kappa_{0}italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are hyperparameters for the prior distributions. Taking the expectations of ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the posterior distibution ğ’©â¢â„â¢ğ’²â¢(ğk,ğšºk|ğk(n),ğš²k(n),Îºk(n),Î½k(n))ğ’©â„ğ’²subscriptğğ‘˜conditionalsubscriptğšºğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğš²ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘˜ğ‘›\mathcal{NIW}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k}|\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}^{(n)},\mbox{\boldmath$% \Lambda$\unboldmath}_{k}^{(n)},\kappa_{k}^{(n)},\nu_{k}^{(n)})caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_W ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), we have the update rules as:

ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†ğ”¼ğ’©â¢â„â¢ğ’²â¢[ğk]=Îº0â¢ğ0+nkâ¢ğ~kÎº0+nk,â†absentsubscriptğ”¼ğ’©â„ğ’²delimited-[]subscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğœ…0subscriptğ0subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜subscript~ğğ‘˜subscriptğœ…0subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜\displaystyle\leftarrow{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{NIW}}[\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{k}]=\tfrac{\kappa_{0}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0}+n_{k}% \widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k}}{\kappa_{0}+n_{k}},â† blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , (14)

where nk=âˆ‘m,jÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘šğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—n_{k}=\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the total virtual word counts used to estimate ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Eq.Â 14 andÂ Eq.Â 15 are the smoothed version ofÂ Eq.Â 7 of the main paper. From the Bayesian perfective, they correspond to the expectations of ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s and ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s posterior distributions. Alg.Â 1 of the main paper summarizes the learning of VALC.

Online Learning of Î¼ksubscriptğœ‡ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that FLMs are deep neural networks trained using minibatches of data, whileÂ Eq.Â 14 andÂ Eq.Â 15 need to go through the whole dataset before each update. Inspired byÂ Hoffman etÂ al. (2010); Oord etÂ al. (2017), we using exponential moving average (EMA) to work with minibatchs. Specifically, we update them as:

ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†Ïâ‹…Nâ‹…ğk+(1âˆ’Ï)â‹…Bâ‹…ğ~k,â†absentâ‹…ğœŒğ‘subscriptğğ‘˜â‹…1ğœŒğµsubscript~ğğ‘˜\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N\cdot\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}+(1% -\rho)\cdot B\cdot\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k},â† italic_Ï â‹… italic_N â‹… bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Ï ) â‹… italic_B â‹… over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†Ïâ‹…Nâ‹…ğšºk+(1âˆ’Ï)â‹…Bâ‹…ğšº~k,â†absentâ‹…ğœŒğ‘subscriptğšºğ‘˜â‹…1ğœŒğµsubscript~ğšºğ‘˜\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N\cdot\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% +(1-\rho)\cdot B\cdot\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}}_{k},â† italic_Ï â‹… italic_N â‹… bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Ï ) â‹… italic_B â‹… over~ start_ARG bold_Î£ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
Nğ‘\displaystyle Nitalic_N â†Ïâ‹…N+(1âˆ’Ï)â‹…B,â†absentâ‹…ğœŒğ‘â‹…1ğœŒğµ\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N+(1-\rho)\cdot B,â† italic_Ï â‹… italic_N + ( 1 - italic_Ï ) â‹… italic_B ,
ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†ğkN,ğšºkâ†ğšºkN,formulae-sequenceâ†absentsubscriptğğ‘˜ğ‘â†subscriptğšºğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜ğ‘\displaystyle\leftarrow\tfrac{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}}{N},\quad% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}\leftarrow\tfrac{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma% $\unboldmath}_{k}}{N},â† divide start_ARG bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† divide start_ARG bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ,

where BğµBitalic_B is the minibatch size, Nğ‘Nitalic_N is a running count, and Ïâˆˆ(0,1)ğœŒ01\rho\in(0,1)italic_Ï âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) is the momentum hyperparameter. ğ~ksubscript~ğğ‘˜\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšº~ksubscript~ğšºğ‘˜\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}}_{k}over~ start_ARG bold_Î£ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the updated ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğšºksubscriptğšºğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT after applyingÂ Eq.Â 14 andÂ Eq.Â 15 only on the current minibatch.

Effect of Attention Weights. Interestingly, we also observe that FLMsâ€™ attention weights on stop words such as â€˜theâ€™ and â€˜aâ€™ tend to be much lower; therefore VALC can naturally ignore these concept-irrelevant stop words when learning and inferring concepts (as discussed inÂ Sec.Â 3.4.2). This is in contrast to typical topic modelsÂ (Blei etÂ al., 2003; Blei, 2012) that require preprocessing to remove stop words.

Phrase-Level Interpretations. We can easily infer phrase-level concepts from word-level concepts by treating phrases as sub-documents and adaptingÂ Eq.Â 6 (which provides document-level concepts) in the paper. Specifically, suppose for a given phrase spanning from the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th word to the sğ‘ sitalic_s-th word in document mğ‘šmitalic_m, we can adaptÂ Eq.Â 6 to provide phrase-level conceptual explanations as Î³mâ¢k(r,s)=Î±k+âˆ‘j=rsÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢jsuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿğ‘ subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘Ÿğ‘ subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—\gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}=\alpha_{k}+\sum_{j=r}^{s}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here Î³mâ¢k(r,s)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿğ‘ \gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the strength of concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k for the given phrase in document mğ‘šmitalic_m. In this way, Î³mâ¢k(r,s)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿğ‘ \gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can serve as the phrase-level concept explanation of the phrase spanning from rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th word to the sğ‘ sitalic_s-th word; this is another interesting complementary sub-document-level concept explanation between the word level and the document level.

Appendix B Interpretation of the ELBO

VALCâ€™s evidence lower bound (ELBO), i.e.,Â Eq.Â 2 in the paper, is

â„’â¢(ğœ¸m,{Ï•mâ£[1:Jm]};Î±,{(ğ[1:K],ğšº[1:K])})â„’subscriptğœ¸ğ‘šsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šdelimited-[]:1subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ›¼subscriptğdelimited-[]:1ğ¾subscriptğšºdelimited-[]:1ğ¾\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{% \boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{m[1:J_{m}]}\};\alpha,\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{[1:K]},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{[1:K]})\})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m [ 1 : italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ; italic_Î± , { ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 : italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 : italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } ) =ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ğœ½m|Î±)]+âˆ‘j=1Jmğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ğ³mâ¢j|ğœ½m)]absentsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘š\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|% \alpha)]+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf z}_{mj}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î± ) ] + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
+âˆ‘j=1Jmğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ğmâ¢j|ğ³mâ¢j,Î¼ğ³mâ¢j,Î£ğ³mâ¢j)]superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptÎ£subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{% \bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]+ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]

(17)

Derivation of the Evidence Lower Bound. We derive the evidence lower bound by computing the log likelihood of each term. For example, by definition, pâ¢(ğmâ¢j|ğ³mâ¢j,Î¼ğ³mâ¢j,Î£ğ³mâ¢j)=[ğ’©â¢(ğmâ¢j;ğmâ¢j,ğšºmâ¢j)]wmâ¢jğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptÎ£subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—superscriptdelimited-[]ğ’©subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—p({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})=[% \mathcal{N}({\bf e}_{mj};\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath% $\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{mj})]^{w_{mj}}italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ğ’©â¢(â‹…)ğ’©â‹…\mathcal{N}(\cdot)caligraphic_N ( â‹… ) is the Gaussian distribution. Then we derive the third term âˆ‘j=1Jmğ”¼ğ•¢â¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ğmâ¢j|ğ³mâ¢j,Î¼ğ³mâ¢j,Î£ğ³mâ¢j)]superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ”¼ğ•¢delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptÎ£subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—\sum_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E_{q}}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}% _{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] inÂ Eq.Â B as follows:

ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ğmâ¢j|ğ³mâ¢j,Î¼ğ³mâ¢j,ğšºğ³mâ¢j)]subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºsubscriptğ³ğ‘šğ‘—\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}% },\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] =âˆ‘kÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kâ¢wmâ¢jâ¢logâ¡ğ’©â¢(ğmâ¢j|ğk,ğšºk)absentsubscriptğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘—ğ’©conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğšºğ‘˜\displaystyle=\sum_{k}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\log\mathcal{N}({\bf e}_{mj}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=âˆ‘kÏ•mâ¢jâ¢kwmâ¢j{âˆ’12(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)Tğšºkâˆ’1(ğmâ¢jâˆ’ğk)\displaystyle=\sum_{k}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
âˆ’log[(2Ï€)d/2|ğšºk|1/2]}.\displaystyle-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}% ]\}.- roman_log [ ( 2 italic_Ï€ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (18)

Expanding the ELBO to the Loss Function. We can expand the ELBO inÂ Eq.Â 2 of the main paper as:

â„’â¢(ğœ¸,Ï•;ğœ¶,{ğ}k=1K,{ğšº}k=1K)=â„’ğœ¸bold-italic-Ï•ğœ¶superscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğšºğ‘˜1ğ¾absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath},\mbox{\boldmath$% \phi$\unboldmath};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}\}_{k=1}^{K},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}\}_{k=1}^{K})=caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î³ , bold_italic_Ï• ; bold_italic_Î± , { bold_italic_Î¼ } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , { bold_Î£ } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = logâ¡ğšªâ¢(âˆ‘k=1KÎ±k)âˆ’âˆ‘k=1Klogâ¡ğšªâ¢(Î±k)+âˆ‘k=1K(Î±kâˆ’1)â¢(Î¨â¢(ğœ¸k)âˆ’Î¨â¢(âˆ‘kâ€²=1Kğœ¸kâ€²))ğšªsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğšªsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜1Î¨subscriptğœ¸ğ‘˜Î¨superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘˜â€²1ğ¾subscriptğœ¸superscriptğ‘˜â€²\displaystyle\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k})% -\sum_{k=1}^{K}\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\alpha_{k})+\sum_{k=1}^% {K}(\alpha_{k}-1)(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{% \prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k^{\prime}}))roman_log bold_Î“ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log bold_Î“ ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) ( roman_Î¨ ( bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Î¨ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
+âˆ‘j=1Jâˆ‘k=1KÏ•jâ¢kâ¢(Î¨â¢(ğœ¸k)âˆ’Î¨â¢(âˆ‘kâ€²=1Kğœ¸kâ€²))superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘—ğ‘˜Î¨subscriptğœ¸ğ‘˜Î¨superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘˜â€²1ğ¾subscriptğœ¸superscriptğ‘˜â€²\displaystyle+\sum_{j=1}^{J}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{jk}(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$% \gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$% \unboldmath}_{k^{\prime}}))+ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Î¨ ( bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Î¨ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
+âˆ‘j,kÏ•jâ¢kâ¢wjâ¢{âˆ’12â¢(ğjâˆ’ğk)Tâ¢ğšºkâˆ’1â¢(ğjâˆ’ğk)âˆ’logâ¡[(2â¢Ï€)d/2â¢|ğšºk|1/2]}subscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—12superscriptsubscriptğğ‘—subscriptğğ‘˜ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğšºğ‘˜1subscriptğğ‘—subscriptğğ‘˜superscript2ğœ‹ğ‘‘2superscriptsubscriptğšºğ‘˜12\displaystyle+\sum_{j,k}\phi_{jk}w_{j}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{j}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{j}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}]\}+ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log [ ( 2 italic_Ï€ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] }
âˆ’logâ¡ğšªâ¢(âˆ‘k=1Kğœ¸j)+âˆ‘k=1Klogâ¡ğšªâ¢(ğœ¸k)âˆ’âˆ‘k=1K(ğœ¸kâˆ’1)â¢(Î¨â¢(ğœ¸k)âˆ’Î¨â¢(âˆ‘kâ€²=1Kğœ¸kâ€²))ğšªsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğœ¸ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğšªsubscriptğœ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğœ¸ğ‘˜1Î¨subscriptğœ¸ğ‘˜Î¨superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘˜â€²1ğ¾subscriptğœ¸superscriptğ‘˜â€²\displaystyle-\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mbox{% \boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{j})+\sum_{k=1}^{K}\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$% \unboldmath}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\mbox{% \boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k}-1)(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k^{% \prime}}))- roman_log bold_Î“ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log bold_Î“ ( bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) ( roman_Î¨ ( bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Î¨ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
âˆ’âˆ‘j=1Jâˆ‘k=1KÏ•jâ¢kâ¢logâ¡Ï•jâ¢k.superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘—ğ‘˜\displaystyle-\sum_{j=1}^{J}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{jk}\log\phi_{jk}.- âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (19)

Definition and Interpretation of the Loss Function. We can interpret the meaning of each term of ELBO as follows:

  • â€¢

    Regularization Term for Document-Level Explanations. The sum of the first and the fourth terms, namely ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ğœ½m|ğœ¶)]âˆ’ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡qâ¢(ğœ½m)]subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šğœ¶subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğœ½ğ‘š{{\mathbb{E}}}_{q}[\log p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath})]-{{\mathbb{E}}}_{q}[\log q(\mbox{\boldmath$% \theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î± ) ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ], is equal to âˆ’KL(q(ğœ½m)|p(ğœ½m|ğœ¶))-KL(q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})|p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$% \unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}))- italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î± ) ), which is the negation of KL Divergence between the variational posterior probability qâ¢(ğœ½m)ğ‘subscriptğœ½ğ‘šq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the prior probability pâ¢(ğœ½m|Î±)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šğ›¼p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\alpha)italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î± ) of the topic proportion ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document mğ‘šmitalic_m. Therefore maximizing the sum of these two terms is equivalent to minimizing the KL Divergence KL(q(ğœ½m)|p(ğœ½m|ğœ¶))KL(q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})|p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$% \unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}))italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î± ) ); this serves as a regularization term to make sure the inferred qâ¢(ğœ½m)ğ‘subscriptğœ½ğ‘šq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is close to its prior distribution pâ¢(ğœ½m|ğœ¶)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘šğœ¶p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath})italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î± ).

  • â€¢

    Regularization Term for Word-Level Explanations. Similarly, the sum of the second and the last terms (ignoring the summation over the word index jğ‘—jitalic_j for simplicity), namely ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(zmâ¢j|ğœ½m)]âˆ’ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡qâ¢(zmâ¢j)]subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—{{\mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]-{{% \mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log q(z_{mj})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] is equal to âˆ’KL(q(zmâ¢j)|p(zmâ¢j|ğœ½m))-KL(q(z_{mj})|p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}))- italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), which is the negation of the KL Divergence between the variational posterior probability qâ¢(zmâ¢j)ğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—q(z_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the prior probability pâ¢(zmâ¢j|ğœ½m)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘šp(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the word-level topic assignment zmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for word jğ‘—jitalic_j of document mğ‘šmitalic_m. Therefore maximizing the sum of these two terms is equivalent to minimizing the KL Divergence KL(q(zmâ¢j)|p(zmâ¢j|ğœ½m))KL(q(z_{mj})|p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}))italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ); this serves as a regularization term to make sure the inferred qâ¢(zmâ¢j)ğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—q(z_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is close to its â€˜priorâ€™ distribution pâ¢(zmâ¢j|ğœ½m)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘šp(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  • â€¢

    Likelihood Term to Indicate How Much FLM Information is Explained. The third term âˆ‘j=1Jmğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ğmâ¢j|zmâ¢j,ğzmâ¢j,ğšºzmâ¢j)]superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{{\mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{% mj}})]âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] is to maximize the log likelihood pâ¢(ğmâ¢j|zmâ¢j,ğzmâ¢j,ğšºzmâ¢j)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of every contextual embedding ğmâ¢jsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘—{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (for word jğ‘—jitalic_j of document mğ‘šmitalic_m) conditioned on the inferred zmâ¢jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the parameters (ğzmâ¢j,ğšºzmâ¢j)subscriptğsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğšºsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘—(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}% _{z_{mj}})( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

In this way, we expand the ELBO to a concrete loss function. Each line ofÂ Eq.Â B corresponds to the expansion of each of the five terms in the ELBO mentioned above (i.e.,Â Eq.Â 2 in the paper).

Appendix C Experimental Settings and Implementation Details

We will release all code, models, and data. Below we provide more details on the experimental settings and practical implementation.

Data Preprocessing and More Datasets.

We follow Terragni etÂ al. (2021) and Zhang etÂ al. (2022) to pre-process these datasets. The statistics of the datasets are summarized inÂ TableÂ 5. We use the standard 8:1:1 train/validation/test set split. We also use the GLUE benchmarkÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2018) to perform additional conceptual interpretation in this section andÂ Sec.Â F. This benchmark includes multiple sub-tasks of predictions, with the paired sentences as inputs. In this paper, we use 4 datasets from GLUE (MRPC, RTE, STS-B, and QQP) to show contextual interpretations. Specifically, we apply VALC to multiple complex natural language understanding (NLU) tasks in the GLUE benchmark. For example, inÂ AppendixÂ F, we show the three-level conceptual explanations of four different tasks in the GLUE benchmark using VALC, i.e.,

  • â€¢

    Microsoft Research Paraphrase Corpus (MRPC), where the task is paraphrase identification and semantic textual similarity,

  • â€¢

    Recognizing Textual Entailment (RTE), where the task is to determine whether one sentence (the premise) entails another sentence (the hypothesis),

  • â€¢

    Semantic Textual Similarity Benchmark (STS-B), where the task is to measure the degree of semantic similarity between pairs of sentences (from 0 to 5), and

  • â€¢

    Quora Question Pairs (QQP), where the task is to classify whether one question is the duplicate of the other.

Implementation. We implemented and trained the model using PyTorchÂ Paszke etÂ al. (2019) on an A5000 GPU with 24GB of memory. The training duration was kept under a few hours for all datasets. We utilized the Adam optimizerÂ Kingma and Ba (2014) with initial learning rates varying between 10âˆ’5âˆ¼10âˆ’3similar-tosuperscript105superscript10310^{-5}\sim 10^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, tailored to the specific requirements of each dataset.

Visualization Postprocessing. For better showcase the dataset-level concepts as inÂ Fig.Â 4 of the main paper, we may employ simple linear transformations on the embedding of words after the aforementioned PCA step, in order to scatter all the informative words on the same figures. However, for some datasets such as STS-B, this is not necessary; therefore we do not use it for these datasets.

Topic (Concept) Identification. Inspired byÂ Blei etÂ al. (2003), we identify meaningful topics by listing the top-5 topics for each word, computing the inverse document frequency (IDF), and filtering out topics with the lowest IDF scores. Note that although GLUE benchmark are datasets that consists of documents with small size, making it particularly challenging for traditional topic models (such as LDA) to learn topics; interestingly our VALC can still perform well in learning the topics. We contribute this to the following observations: (1) Compared to traditional LDA using discrete word representations, VALC uses continuous word embeddings. In such a continuous space, topics learned for one word can also help neighboring words; this alleviates the sparsity issue caused by short documents and therefore learns better topics. (2) VALCâ€™s attention-based continuous word counts further improves sample efficiency. In VALC, important words have larger attention weights and therefore larger continuous word counts. In this case, one important word in a sentence possesses statistical (sample) power equivalent to multiple words; this leads to better sample efficiency in VALC.

Computational Complexity. Our VALC introduces minimal overhead in terms of model training cost. Specifically, VALCâ€™s computational complexity is Oâ¢(Tâ¢Kâ¢d2)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡ğ¾superscriptğ‘‘2O(TKd^{2})italic_O ( italic_T italic_K italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is the number of epochs (a small number, such as 3, is sufficient for convergence), Kğ¾Kitalic_K is the number of concepts, and dğ‘‘ditalic_d is the dimension of the embeddings (in hidden layers). This means that VALCâ€™s computational cost scales linearly with the number of concepts Kğ¾Kitalic_K (similar to existing methods).

More NLP Tasks. VALC can be naturally applied to other NLP tasks, such as named entity recognition (NER), reading comprehension, or question answering. Specifically, these tasks involve transformer predictions from multiple positions within the context, rather than relying solely on the â€˜CLSâ€™ token. For example, NER predicts each token in the document as the beginning (â€˜Bâ€™) of an entity, the inside (â€˜Iâ€™) of entities, etc. To accommodate this and use VALC to explain each token jğ‘—jitalic_j in the context, we can substitute the attention from the â€˜CLSâ€™ token with (1) the attention from the â€˜CLSâ€™ token to all tokens of the previous layer with (2) the attention from token jğ‘—jitalic_j to all tokens of the previous layer in transformers (e.g., using the attention weights from the predicted label â€˜Bâ€™ to all tokens of the previous layer as ğšmsubscriptğšğ‘š{\bf a}_{m}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in VALC). This adaptation allows VALC to maintain its explanatory power across various NLP applications, demonstrating its versatility and effectiveness in a wide range of tasks.

Appendix D More Details on Concept Editing

We perform concept pruning to the CLS embeddings for VALC (details inÂ Alg. 2). Since BERTopic and CETopic can infer concepts (topics) only at the document level, their only choice is to prune a concept by completely removing input tokens assigned to the concept (as mentioned inÂ Sec.Â 5.1 and 5.2). To compare our learned concepts with the baseline models, we first follow their configurationsÂ (Grootendorst, 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2022) to fix BERT model parameters when learning the topics/concepts, train a classifier on top of the fixed contextual embeddings, and then perform concept pruningÂ (Koh etÂ al., 2020) for different evaluated models on the same classifier. Note that concept editing is deterministic; therefore, we conduct our experiments with a single run.

Specifically, we assume each BERT model contains a backbone and a classifier. To perform concept editing:

  • (1)

    We first train a classifier on top of the fixed BERT embeddings generated by the fixed backbone to get the original accuracy in the â€˜Uneditedâ€™ column (inÂ TableÂ 2 andÂ TableÂ 3 of the main paper).

  • (2)

    We then apply the same embedding cluster methods to these BERT embeddings to infer the concepts/topics for each dataset.

  • (3)

    Finally, with the inferred concepts/topics from the baselines (SHAP/LIME, BERTopic and CETopic inÂ TableÂ 2 of the main paper) and our VALC variants (Unweighted and Weighted inÂ TableÂ 3 of the main paper), we perform concept editing and feed the concept-edited embeddings into the trained classifier from Step (1) to compute the editing accuracy for different methods.

Since here one does not fully finetune the BERT model (i.e., keeping the backbone fixed), the editing accuracy is expected to be lower than the â€˜Finetuneâ€™ column (inÂ TableÂ 2 andÂ TableÂ 3 of the main paper), which serves as the oracle.Â TableÂ 2 of the main paper shows that our VALC learns better concepts than the baselines, andÂ TableÂ 3 of the main paper shows that the weighted variant of VALC performs better.

Note that SHAP and LIME both interpret the CLS tokenâ€™s embedding, and hence their concept vectors have the same dimension as the FLM embedding vector (768 in our case). When we conduct concept editing on the kğ‘˜kitalic_kâ€™th dimension/concept, we simply subtract the CLS embeddingâ€™s dimension kğ‘˜kitalic_k with the average value in the batch on dimension kğ‘˜kitalic_k (which means that we know little about the concept/dimension kğ‘˜kitalic_k on this document), and keep values of the other dimensions unchanged. Note that the pruning process is exactly the same for SHAP and LIME. Therefore SHAP and LIME have identical test accuracy and accuracy gain.

Document-Level Concept Editing. We describe the document-level concept editing algorithm of VALC inÂ Alg.Â 3. cmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šc_{m}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the â€˜CLSâ€™ embedding of document mğ‘šmitalic_m (seeÂ Fig.Â 2 of the main paper).

Appendix E Connections Between the Defined Properties and Empirical Results

VALC is able to show which words or embeddings contributed to the document-level concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Specifically, our variational parameter (a vector) Ï•mâ¢jâˆˆâ„Ksubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ¾\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT describes how much word jğ‘—jitalic_j contributes to document mğ‘šmitalic_m. For example, the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-th entry of Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted as Ï•mâ¢jâ¢ksubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜\phi_{mjk}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the paper, describes how much word jğ‘—jitalic_j contributes to document mğ‘šmitalic_m in terms of concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Therefore, one could use argâ¡maxjâ¡Ï•mâ¢jâ¢ksubscriptğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘˜\arg\max_{j}\phi_{mjk}roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to find the word that contributes most to document mğ‘šmitalic_mâ€™s concept kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Below, we will explain these four properties usingÂ Fig.Â 4 as a running example.

  • (1)

    Multi-Level Structure ensures that VALC learns the dataset-, document-, and word-level concepts jointly. In Fig.Â 4:

    • â€“

      Dataset-level concepts are highlighted by the top words of each concept (the top right box of Fig.Â 4) and the distribution of their embeddings in the FLM (left and middle figures of Fig.Â 4); for example, Concept 5 (data analysis) is marked in red.

    • â€“

      Document-level concepts are demonstrated by each documentâ€™s topic; for instance, in the box for document (a) in Fig.Â 4 (right), VALC identifies Topic (Concept) 5 as key to the FLMâ€™s prediction of the label 3 (computer science).

    • â€“

      Word-level concepts are identified by words in documents. For example, in the box for document (a) in Fig.Â 4, VALC highlights the words â€˜geneticâ€™ and â€˜neuralâ€™ because they are highly related to Concept 5 (data analysis). Terms like â€˜genetic algorithmsâ€™ and â€˜neural networksâ€™ are related to data analysis, aligning with the document-level concept.

  • (2)

    Normalization ensures that concept learning is regulated and smoothed, with inferred concepts appearing reasonable. Specifically, in the document-level explanation ğœ½msubscriptğœ½ğ‘š\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and word-level explanation Ï•mâ¢jsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘—\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, all concepts are assigned a value within the range of 0âˆ¼1similar-to010\sim 10 âˆ¼ 1, and all entries sum up to 1, i.e., âˆ‘k=1KÏ•mâ¢iâ¢jâ¢k=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mijk}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸mâ¢k=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘˜1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. This introduces â€˜competitionâ€™ among different concepts; a larger strength for one concept means smaller strength for other concepts. Therefore, together with the help of the Dirichlet prior, it implicitly encourages sparser concept-level explanations Î¸msubscriptğœƒğ‘š\theta_{m}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are more aligned with humansâ€™ cognitive processes and more human-understandable (humans tend to make decisions with a small set of concepts).

  • (3)

    Additivity enables FLMs to incorporate relevant concepts and exclude irrelevant ones, thereby enhancing prediction accuracy (as shown inÂ TableÂ 2 andÂ TableÂ 3). For example, in document (a) of Fig.Â 4, VALC identifies Concept 5 as a highly related concept, distinguishing it from less related concepts. In practice, this may help practitioners identify key concepts in model prediction and more effectively intervene to improve model prediction accuracy (e.g., an expert may find that a concept is relevant and manually down-weight the concept to enhance the modelâ€™s prediction).

  • (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization ensures a strong correlation between (1) VALCâ€™s generated concept explanations and (2) the explained modelâ€™s representation and predictions. In other words, it ensures that VALC is explaining the target FLM, rather than generating concept explanations irrelevant to the target FLM. For instance, in document (a) of Fig.Â 4, the inferred document-level Concept 5 (data analysis) effectively explains the FLM prediction, i.e., label 3 (computer science), by highlighting the intrinsic link between the data analysis concept and the class label computer science. This connection is evidenced by the words in dataset-level Concept 5 (top right box). The mutual information between the inferred Concept 5 (data analysis) and label 3 (computer science) contributes to generating high-quality explanations.

Appendix F More Conceptual Interpretation Results in Different Downstream Tasks

Dataset-Level Interpretations. As in the main paper, we leverage VALC as an interpreter on MRPC, RTE, STS-B and QQP, respectively, sample 3,3,4,433443,3,4,43 , 3 , 4 , 4 concepts (topics) for each dataset respectively, and plot the word embeddings of the top words (closest to the center ğisubscriptğğ‘–\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in these concepts using PCA. Fig.Â 6(left) shows the concepts from MRPC. We can observe Concept 20 is mostly about policing, including words such as â€˜suspectâ€™, â€˜policeâ€™, and â€˜houseâ€™. Concept 24 is mostly about politics, including words such as â€˜capitalâ€™, â€˜Congressâ€™, and â€˜Senateâ€™. Concept 27 contains mostly names such as â€˜Margaretâ€™ and â€˜Maryâ€™. Similarly, Fig.Â 6(right) shows the concepts from RTE. We can observe Concept 67 is related to West Asia and includes words such as â€˜Quranâ€™ and â€˜Pashaâ€™. Concept 13 is related to Europe and includes European countries/names such as â€˜Prussiaâ€™ and â€˜Salzburgâ€™. Concept 91 is mostly about healthcare and includes words such as â€˜physiologyâ€™ and â€˜insulinâ€™. Fig.Â 7 shows the concepts from STS-B. We can observe Concept 63 is mostly about household and daily life, including words such as â€˜trashâ€™, â€˜flowersâ€™, â€˜airsâ€™, and â€˜gardenâ€™. Concept 60 is mostly about tools, including words such as â€˜stationsâ€™, â€˜ropeâ€™, â€˜parachuteâ€™, and â€˜hoseâ€™. Concept 84 is mostly about national security, including words such as â€˜guerillaâ€™, â€˜NSAâ€™, â€˜espionageâ€™, and â€˜raidedâ€™. Concept 55 contains mostly countries and cities such as â€˜Kievâ€™, â€˜Moscowâ€™, â€˜Algeriaâ€™, and â€˜Ukrainianâ€™. Similarly, Fig.Â 8 shows the concepts from QQP. We can observe that Concept 12 is mostly about negative attitude, including words such as â€˜boringâ€™, â€˜criticismâ€™, and â€™blameâ€™. Concept 73 is mostly about Psychology, including words such as â€˜adrenalineâ€™, â€˜hauntingâ€™, and â€™paranoiaâ€™. Concept 34 is mostly about prevention and conservatives, including words such as â€˜destroysâ€™, â€˜unacceptableâ€™, and â€™prohibitsâ€™. Concept 64 is mostly about strategies, including words such as â€˜rumoursâ€™, â€˜boycottâ€™, and â€™deportationâ€™.

Document-Level Interpretations. For document-level conceptual interpretations, we sample two example documents from MRPC (Fig.Â 6(left)), three from RTE (Fig.Â 6(right)), six from STS-B (Fig.Â 7) and eight from QQP (Fig.Â 8), respectively, where each document contains a pair of sentences. The MRPC task is to predict whether one sentence paraphrases the other. For example, in the first document of MRPC, we can see that our VALC correctly interprets the model prediction â€˜Trueâ€™ with Concept 24 (politics). The RTE task is to predict whether one sentence entail the other. For example, in the second document of RTE, VALC correctly interprets the model prediction â€˜Trueâ€™ with Concept 13 (countries). The STS-B task is to predict the semantic similarity between two sentences with the score range of [0,5]05[0,5][ 0 , 5 ]. For example, in DocumentÂ (a) of Fig.Â 7, we can see that VALC correctly interpret the modelâ€™s predicted similarity score â€˜0.1180.1180.1180.118â€™ (which is relatively low,) with Concept 63 (household and daily life) and Concept 60 (tools). Similarly, in DocumentÂ (f) of Fig.Â 7, we can see that VALC correctly interpret the modelâ€™s predicted similarity score â€˜4.6724.6724.6724.672â€™ (which is relatively high) with Concept 84 (national security). The QQP task is to predict whether the two questions are paraphrase of each other. For example, in DocumentÂ (b) of Fig.Â 8, we can see that VALC correctly interprets the modelâ€™s predicted label â€˜Falseâ€™ with Concept 73 (Psychology). Similarly, in DocumentÂ (e) of Fig.Â 8, we can see that VALC correctly interprets the modelâ€™s predicted label â€˜Trueâ€™ with Concept 64 (strategies).

Word-Level Interpretations. For word-level conceptual interpretations, we can observe that VALC interpret the FLMâ€™s prediction on MRPCâ€™s first document (Fig.Â 6(left)) using words such as â€˜senateâ€™ and â€˜bittyâ€™ that are related to politics. Note that the word â€˜bittyâ€™ is commonly used (with â€˜littleâ€™) by politicians to refer to the small size of tax relief/cut plans. Similarly, for RTEâ€™s first document (Fig.Â 6(right)), VALC correctly identifies Concept 67 (West Asia) and interprets the model prediction â€˜Falseâ€™ by distinguishing between keywords such as â€˜Jihadâ€™ and â€˜Al Qaedaâ€™. likewise, we can observe that VALC interprets FLMâ€™s prediction on DocumentÂ (c) of Fig.Â 7 using words such as â€˜catâ€™, â€˜floorâ€™, and â€˜garlicâ€™ that are related to household and daily life. Also, VALC interprets FLMâ€™s prediction on DocumentÂ (e) of Fig.Â 7 using words such as â€˜soldierâ€™ and â€˜borderâ€™ that are related to national security. Similarly, for QQPâ€™s DocumentÂ (d) (Fig.Â 8), VALC correctly interprets the model prediction â€˜Trueâ€™ by identifying keywords such as â€˜sabotageâ€™ and â€˜opposeâ€™ with similar meanings in the topic of strategies. For QQPâ€™s DocumentÂ (g), (Fig.Â 8), VALC interprets the words in the both sentences with the same semantics, such as â€˜conservativeâ€™ that is related to prevention and conservatives (note that in politics, â€˜conservativeâ€™ refers to parties that tend to prevent/block new policies or legislation), and thereby predicting the correct label â€˜Trueâ€™.

Example Concepts.

FollowingÂ Blei etÂ al. (2003), we show the learned concepts on the RTE dataset inÂ TableÂ 6, which is complementary to aforementioned explanations. We select several different topics fromÂ Fig.Â 6. As in Sec. 5.4 of the main paper, we obtain top words from each concept via first calculating the average of the each wordâ€™s corresponding contextual embeddings over the dataset, and then getting the nearest words to each topic center (ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in the embedding space. As we can see inÂ TableÂ 6, VALC can capture various concepts with profound and accurate semantics. Therefore, although FLM embeddings are contextual and continuous, our VALC can still find conceptual patterns of words on the dataset-level.

Appendix G More Quantitative Results.

Document Classification with VALC Concepts. We conducted additional experiments to perform document classification using the â€˜CLSâ€™ tokenâ€™s embedding and ğœ½ğœ½\thetabold_italic_Î¸ (inferred from VALC) as features.Â TableÂ 7 shows the results on three datasets. The results show that our VALC can learn meaningful concept vector ğœ½ğœ½\thetabold_italic_Î¸, which can improve model predictions of document labels.

Appendix H Theory on the Mutual Information Maximization Property

We provide the following proof of Theorem 4.1 of the main paper.

For convenience, let Î©=(ğk=1K,Î£k=1K)Î©superscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘˜1ğ¾\Omega=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k=1}^{K},\Sigma_{k=1}^{K})roman_Î© = ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and Î²=(ğœ½m,ğ³m)ğ›½subscriptğœ½ğ‘šsubscriptğ³ğ‘š\beta=(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},{\bf z}_{m})italic_Î² = ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

We then introduce a helper joint distribution of the variables ğmsubscriptğğ‘š{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², sâ¢(ğm,Î²)=pâ¢(ğm)â¢qâ¢(Î²|ğm)ğ‘ subscriptğğ‘šğ›½ğ‘subscriptğğ‘šğ‘conditionalğ›½subscriptğğ‘šs({\bf e}_{m},\beta)=p({\bf e}_{m})q(\beta|{\bf e}_{m})italic_s ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î² ) = italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_Î² | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

According to the definition of ELBO of Section 3.4.1, inÂ Eq.Â 4.1, we have
